138780961.review:
So, imagine taking the gameplay mechanics of King's Bounty, you know, that game everyone raves about, and combining it with a linear map progression system. What do you get? A game so uninspiring and forgettable that you can easily find in any app store. Exciting, right?

Now, don't get me wrong, I don't regret playing it or anything. I just felt like there was something missing, like a spark of excitement or a reason to care. But hey, the graphics were alright, such as the sound effects and music

As for the story, well, it was there. You know, just filling in the blanks and giving you a reason to keep playing. But let's be honest, did I feel immersed? Not really. It was more like going through the motions, ticking off boxes without any real emotional investment

Sure, the battle mechanics are decent, and if that's your thing, then hooray. But let's not kid ourselves, everything outside of the battlefield was about as captivating as a conversation with a brick wall. No surprises, no depth, just a flat turn-based experience to pass the time

But here's the kicker, folks: This game comes at a price that won't break the bank. So, if you're in the market for an on-the-go turn-based game where you can tune out the world and not strain your brain with innovative strategies, then by all means, give it a shot

The neutral button would be appropriate here .....

So, this is a mobile game ported to the PC. It works fine, there are no issues with it.

In terms of story, gameplay and visuals its very simplistic.
The story is baseline and moves you along with some light dialog, gameplay has enough depth to make you think a little, but nothing too challenging and visuals are perfectly fine as well, nothing bad, but nothing stands out.
There is a campaign, which you can complete in around 2-3 hours and a survival mode, but that one feels too random for my taste.
I played this while doing something else, so it served its purpose well. I got all the achievements from the second playthrough, so nothing tedious.
Everything seems fine, it did its job to help lower my need for distractions. Theres nothing wrong with a generic game, they have their place in the market. In fact, I feel we dont really have enough decent ones.

But would I recommend it for the current asking price of 6,59 Euros? Im afraid not... 3-4 would seem reasonable for a recommendation, but at this price I would be a bit more critical. 

I got this in a cheap bundle with the other games of the series, so Im pretty satisfied with my purchase. Its a pretty nice side game. But at this point its more expensive than something like Return to Castle Wolfenstein and it offers neither the same intensity of gameplay, nor length.

4.5/10

118914341.review:
Works well on Linux Ubuntu.

A brief and simple yet amusing RPG game where you simply visit each location and your choices don't really matter. Music is nice albeit repetitive, graphics are amusing enough and the sounds fit the gaming experience.

It is very short, approximately 4 to 5 hours long and you will find different types of units (of which you can use 5 at most per fight), approximately 9 pieces of equipment and you will engage in roughly 35 fights. Units are stacked but the stacks can not be split.

Upon losing a fight, you will gain a little money and get all of your units back and upon winning a fight, you will gain a lot of money minus the cost for reviving your units. This leads to you either picking fights that you are absolutely sure you can win (so you get the most money) or to you losing fights and still get paid. If you pick fights that you can only barely win, you'll be shooting yourself in the foot as you'll be paid less due to the revive costs. 

I recommend playing this on HARD difficulty right away to get the most out of your money as there is zero replay value.

Still, recommended at this price.

114866003.review:
Braveland is a game I would call an "RPG lite", the game is fun but is very basic RPG that would be a relaxing play for an experienced player and more challenging to players new to the genre and also under age 13.  The graphics are nice as well as the sound effects and music.

The map of the game as well as the battlefields will remind people of some time management series of the past. You will be able to choose from seven different units for your army as you unlock them by acquiring xp. You also acquire coins to spend on units, unit special abilities as well as four things for your hero to wear/weapon. You will also have a special ability to use during battle, as if your hero calls when to use it.  There will be 5 abilities total as you advance on the map and unlock them.

The game breaks down to being able to buy enough units and knowing which ones to use and not waste coins spending them on units you will not be using later and how you move your units on the battlefield. Battles are turn-based with very few options to use for your units. You can move, delay your move, attack or put up a defense each turn for your units. Nearly all units have a special ability that you can choose to use, however once used you will have to wait a few turns before you can use it again.

Game is recommended as a first RPG game to get the feel of it, if the player is playing for the first time. If you want a challenge, avoid. Best to get on sale as well, as there isn't a lot of playtime involved, I have 23.4 hours in the game but left it running a few times while doing chores. Achievements are very easy, so 100% is simple.

[h1]Don’t buy games on sale..[/h1]

I have no idea when I bought this game (guessing about 4 years ago), but apparently I had 3 hours of playtime on it, so I installed it and finished it.. in 3.7 hrs approx. 

While I sat there mildly annoyed, I realized, it’s my fault for buying random indie games when they look like obvious mobile ports (and this is). Whatever, lemme review this dumpster fire and move on.

[h1]PROS[/h1]
[list]
[*] ART. To be specific, the random sketches done by artists, probably concept art, used as cinematics mostly. In-game visuals are garbage ones you see in every other kiddy mobile game. Not sure this is much of a “pros”, but I had to enter something.

[/list]



[h1]CONS[/h1]
[list]
[*] EVERYTHING ELSE: From garbage turn-based “gameplay” that will put you to sleep, to attempt at having a story (they don’t) that goes nowhere fast (I started a new game after finishing just to be sure what it was about), this has to be a perfect example of a mobile game that should NEVER exist on PC. 

But we are living in a reality where all trash from mobiles is dumped on PC and ends up getting glorious reviews from people who just discovered PC gaming.

Oh and do you see “BOOK-1” somewhere on the store page? Do a Ctrl+F and see if you can find “BOOK” at all.

You can’t find it?

Well then you’ll love the fact that the game ends with information about “THIS IS BOOK 1, PLAY OTHER BOOKS” (something like that).

So yeah, this garbage dump of a mobile game has “books” like it matters. I wouldn’t have reviewed this game at all if not for this game having the balls to tell me to buy more “books”, like it’s Lord of the Rings waiting to be explored, a journey as old as time.





[h1]TLDR;[/h1] 
Instead of wasting money on such games, buy indie games that deserve your money. There are a lot of developers who put actual time and effort into making something new or improving upon other games that came before them.

If you go to the developer’s site for Braveland, you can see that these people churn out generic trash on mobile and quickly export it to PC as well (doesn’t take much to do it, trust me).

103972813.review:
Even though this game started on Android platform, it is ported very well, better than the Ubisoft's PC ports, and even though in its nature it is short, it still provides hours of fun. It is a Turn Based Strategy, with hexagonal movements. It has three difficulty levels for more challenge and more hours of gameplay.

This game doesn't provide any dialogue options, nor can the story be affected, altered, defined, nor shaped through any player actions. What it provides is a choice of mercenaries that can be recruited for combat, and the items that the player want to equip.

It works like this: some fancy hero wants to save the day from an evil king, as it usually goes, and on his way he recruits units to help him out. Some join as a reward for freeing them, some for assisting them, while others be recruited for coin. The dumbest part here is that the hero itself doesn't participate in the fights. The protagonist is just a manager, while the antagonist does participate in the fighting. In my opinion he should have been featured as a hero fighter.

The following are available unit types: peasants, pathfinders (dual-wield rangers/rouges), archers, healers, footmen (sword and shield), arbalesters (crossbowmen) and knights (two-handed). Unit types have unit stacks, which are represented with numbers and a health bar. The higher the number the more soldiers the unit has. As the helth points drop, units get killed, and the numbers decrease. Each unit is visually represented by a single soldier. Each unit has a star value, which is there to provide some insight in the power of the unit, and to impose the limit of 15 stars a warband can have. This way the developers have established the balancing of the game, and the unit limits. The maximum number of units is 5 at any given time, but it can be smaller if the player wants to recruit more of the unit types with the higher star ranking. it supposed to be like the higher the star rating of the unit, the better and stronger the unit. But, I will explain what is the problem here in the continuation of the review.

The player navigates on the linear, semi-open world map, and picks the fights, recruits units and buys the equipment. After every battle the player receives the experience points and gold coins. Gold reward will be diminished for every unit lost during the fights. The higher the casualties the less of the reward player receives. During the fights, gold can be dropped by the enemies, and some battles have gold chests on the map. Interacting with the chest during the battle counts as an action, and the unit which has opened the chest can not attack. The equipment items are few in numbers and are expensive. They provide the bonuses for spirit, attack, physical defense and magical defense, as well as specialised damage bonuses for certain unit types. That way the player can role-play the warband. Those are a hat/helmet, cape/chest armour, belt and a weapon.

Battles are turn-based. Units have limited moves on the hexagons. Their movement speed depends on the unit type per se. Pathfinders can traverse the largest distance, while footmen are some of the slowest in the game, thus traverse shorter distances. Except for the peasants, every other unit has one special attack, which, once used, will take couple of turns to recharge. Also, there are special magical powers that player can use, for the cost of the rage points. Each hit received fills the rage bar. Special powers can be used to buff the defenses of the unit, attack the enemy units, and so on. Units, besides their special attacks have their pros and cons, which the player must learn how to use to his/her advantage. For example, archers are ranged units, but if they shoot from the longer range their attacks are weaker. The ideal option is to place them two hexagons away from the target. But, in that case they become too exposed, and considering they are the archers, they are squishier than other units, so they can suffer lots of casualties by the melee opponents. If the enemy unit gets placed one hexagon in front of them, they can not do their ranged attacks, but have to either switch to weak melee attack or to step away and then shoot. Arbalesters, which are crossbowmen, can shoot from the furthest corner of the map, and harm the targets better than the archers. The further away from the target they are, the harder they hit. Those are examples of how the player must develop strategy starting from the arranging the layout, or should I say the formation of the units, before the battle starts and then, covering the ranged units with the melee units, flaking the enemy units, locking the enemy ranged units, and so on. Peasants are the only unit without special abilities, but if the player has chosen the equipment which boosts the damage of all units, they can critically hit hard certain unit types, which makes up for their lack of the special ability. Also, they are the cheapest and the most numerous unit in the game.

As for the cons, the fact that the hero is not participating in the fights, but is only visually representing the warband on the world map, does not leave a convincing impression that he is in to get the evil king. The fact that he is just a mere unit manager, and not a hero who would lead the charge in the battles, takes away from the story itself, especially at the end of the game, where he stands triumphant over the evil king, as depicted in the cutscenes. The balancing is the main issue of the game that matters. For example, healers are utterly useless. Their attack damage is the lowest of all units in the game, including the enemies, yet in order to heal, they have to use their special ability. The healing spell is so weak, that the health regained is not relevant, compared to the enemy's damage output, which can smite couple of units in one hit. Yet healers heal 18 life at most, which is not enough to heal one allied unit for the full health bar. Once a player uses the healing spell, the healer can not attack, nor make any other action. And the worst yet is that a healer can only cast healing spell twice per battle, and the cooldown takes around three turns. Having them in the warband is a waste of turns, and they can only serve as a meat canon, but not for long either, as they are the squishiest unit in the game. There is one more mage unit type in the game, elementalists, the strong mage type worth being in the warband, but that unit is not available in the story mode by the stupid choice the developers have made. They are only available in the second mode of the game called survival mode, where players compete for the highscore. Another problem are the knights, which come last to join the hero. If they join the last, they are the strongest melee unit one would think. Especially since they have the 5 star rating, the highest star rating in the game, accompanied only by the arbalesters. The problem with them is that their damage output is inferior to peasants and pathfinders, units available right at the beginning of the game. Their special ability is an area of effect ground slam, which deals unimpressive damage.

All in all, it is a fun little game, and deserves the rating of 4/5. It is not special, but it can provide hours of fun even after one beats the game on all three difficulties.

From the very beginning of the game, I had the feeling that I was playing some Kings Bounty or the first parts of the HoMM games.

A simple and not too intricate plot, turn-based battles, abilities, magic, and all this is implemented simply, logically, interestingly and knowledgeably.

93712189.review:
Braveland is a fairly shallow turn based tactical strategy game. The main story is very short (~5 hrs or so to complete hard difficulty run), is bland and shallow with weak writing or quests. Very linear without interesting choices and no real replayability.

The combat mechanics are just as shallow. There's a general lack of units, skills, items, etc. Lacks mechanics like cover and doing well in battles largely comes down to buying more men with gold. The one real choice you will make is to decide which units to bring as you're limited in which units to use. Not very difficult overall and if you have issues, when you flee from a fight or even lose it, you get bonus gold which you can use to buy more upgrades.

There is a 'Survival' mode, where you spend gold on a random choice of upgrades and units and allies that die don't respawn. You fight an escalating series of 10 battles until you (most likely) die. Tried it once after finishing the main story but don't combat isn't interesting enough to make it fun.

On the other hand, if you pick the game up on sale it's only like $2. So it can serve as a bit of a distraction I guess.

Braveland is a great introduction to hexagonal style board games. For kids, or those who otherwise are new to the turn based games, this is a good place to start. The tutorial leads you through several encounters, showing you what different abilities can be used with various characters.

With bright colors, non-gore violence (no blood), a simple storyline with easy to read script, I would say that it is fine for kids to play.

However, if you find that you are dominating the levels easily, and want to force yourself to make it a true strategy victory, then I suggest playing on the most difficult level. This will also guarantee several achievements that can only be done on the hardest difficulty. 

+RECOMMEND for those who like: non-gore deaths, turned based strategy, or are new gamers

73674779.review:
Simple, cheap, short, and pretty easy. If any of those things offend you, this may not be the game for you.

SIMPLE: The mechanics are 100% HOMM, but even simpler if you can believe that. One small difference is that it caps the quantity and quality of your army. Why? Because your units never really die. (More on that later.)

CHEAP: You can get a bundle of the whole trilogy for next to nothing.

SHORT: If you're very slow, you MIGHT get your hour count into the double digits.

EASY: I'm pretty sure it's literally impossible to lose. Your units are fully healed after every battle (even the "dead" ones). If you are utterly defeated, all your units are restored AND the game gives you some extra gold as a condolence.

All that said, none of this actually makes it a bad game. It's a cute, relaxing way to get an accomplishment fix for when you don't feel like trying too hard. There's definitely room in the market for a game like that, and plenty of people it will appeal to. So even though I don't necessarily take it seriously as a game, I feel OK about recommending it.

73622350.review:
[h1]IN A WORD: [b]MAYBE[/b] [/h1] 
[h1]IN SHORT:[/h1]
[quote=]
[b]WHAT TO EXPECT:[/b] Casual.  Short. Cheap. Cliched fantasy theme, story and setting. Barely adequate-sized campaign. Balanced, if mostly linear world map. Shallow hex-based tactical battles.  Turnbased combat. Basic but functional gameplay. Limited management elements. Unimaginitive enemy types. Basic combat and ability power mechanics. Clean, minimalist art style. Simple soundtrack. Singleplayer only.
[b]ACHIEVEMENTS:[/b] EASY. WELL CONCIEVED.
[b]STATUS:[/b] COMPLETE.
[b]WHEN TO BUY:[/b] ON SALE. AND w/ OTHER TITLES in IP.[/quote]

[i]More info below....[/i]

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2415861678
[h1]THE LOWDOWN:[/h1]
Braveland is a fantasy themed game were a series of tactical battles are fought on hex-based maps.  Lead an army across a horizontally scrolling map of the world.  Move them from location to location.  Fight battles. Defeat enemies.  Receive XP to level your general and gold to purchase items for your general.  Obtain warriors for your army.  As your army defeats enemies and liberates locations you can; recruit replacements and better units, gain rewards to increase your general's stats and special combat abilities, purchase unit powers and, obtain weapons and items to boost the general's stats.  

Before combat organise your army from the small number of unit types available and acquired.  Units include: militia, thieves, archers, crossbowmen, healers, armoured warriors and knights.  Move units into melee combat.  Have ranged units fire from distance.  Use unit and your general's abilities for tactical benefit.  Purchase replacements for fallen warriors.  Purchase and equipment items to your general's inventory.  Rinse and repeat.  Until the final battle.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2415857286
[h1]THE GOOD:[/h1]
+ Conceptually well designed and implemented.
+ Well balanced scrolling overland map.
+ Clean well-drawn cartoony graphics.
+ Preview detail showing potential encounter difficulty.

[h1]THE BAD:[/h1]
- Overall too linear.
- Not enough dynamic elements. I.e. Battle numbers, enemy composition etc.
- Playthroughs on separate difficulties are not unique enough.
- Not enough unit types.  

[h1]AND THE REST:[/h1]
* Fun if cliche fantasy theme, story and setting.
* Short and fairly simplistic battles.
* Simple but balanced gameplay mechanics.
* Robust but simple enemy AI.
* Dozens of user determined encounters.  Most are linear.
* A basic but apt soundtrack.
* Small inventory with stat boosting items, for the army general.
* Some dynamic changes to battle maps layouts.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2415859923
[h1]ANALYSIS:[/h1]
Braveland proved to be a fairly enjoyable if run-of-the-mill experience.  Aesthetically the graphics and soundtrack are exactly what to expect from a low-budget indie title but together it does the job.  The overall design and implementation is about perfect for the game in hand.  

Playing the game was positive if rather shallow.  The UGO-WEGO combat mechanism works well but fighting battles is too short.  Every encounter feels over-refined in that there are just enough enemies to cause problems but never really defeat the player.  This is compounded by an enemy AI that lacks any sophistication.  Really unless the player makes a mistake with the order some encounters are fought in, there is little to worry about.  

Management is also a very basic affair with all to limited inventory and army configuration options.  As was the journey taken across the overland map to reach the final battle to defeat the game.  Even though there were a few choices as to which encounter to undertake, only one path was really possible to minimise casualties. While playing through this game it became clear that alot of polish went into making what is a very smooth and balanced game.  The lack of content maybe a minor problem to some but I found it to be maybe just shy of what I hoped for.

[h1]VERDICT:[/h1]
Overall I consider Braveland to be repetitive and fairly shallow.  Maybe thats due to its casual and mobile port origins.  Even if thats the case, its a decent fantasy themed turn-based tactical 'war' game with limited management elements.  Its complete and polished production could take it from a Maybe to a Recommendation if you can overlook the numerous limitations.  There are larger, more detailed games of this genre out there but if you fancy something a little lighter then this is a good place to start.  Its fairly cheap and there are already three sequels released from this IP.  So if you find yourself enjoying this game you could look into getting those as well, even at the same time.  Some of them are cheap and/or bundled up.

[quote=]Thank you for reading. | Find my reviews [url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/nourl1/recommended/]here[/url].[/quote]

"Your army will be too strong"

It is funny that for a commander that needs an army to fight his enemies you are not allowed to bring too many units to battle. Not to mention that the main character doesn't even participate in the battle, instead you hire units like Archers and Knights to fight on a hexagonal grid.

The grid doesn't really do anything innovative or interesting instead, relying on the tried and true choke points. These choke points will be utilized to mostly block your enemies from bum-rushing your archers and healers.

The entire game plays like an average mobile game with crisp yet uninspiring graphics and art, why do I say this? Because each and every unit has the same two dots for eyes and a curved line for a smile, clearly a lack of effort by the art team, not to mention that the healer has a literal DERP face.

User interface needs a lot of more work, where somehow the "simple" buttons on the screen only seek to confuse the player initially.

It's a mobile game, an overall meh mobile game, but I will concede that this is better than MONMUSU.

72645004.review: I gave it some time but I just could not get into this one. I don't think it's worth $6.99 and I don't think it's worth your time unless you really have nothing better to do. It's obviously a mobile game...there are huge buttons everywhere and simple systems. I do mean simple. The game is about numbers and how much you can stack up of a certain unit. The higher the number, the stronger the unit is. When you enter a combat the game becomes about simple attrition. You just keep running your units into the other side until they reach zero. To be fair there are some things that are introduced to spice up the game like hero equipment and spells, but the impact they make on the experience is minimal. It all boils down to how fat your units are, not your tactics or equipment. The board is a bit small to maneuver and things like line of sight, cover, turn order, and unit cohesion are non-factors here. I love tactical games and this one kept me interested longer than it should have for that reason. I just think there are better games for the price that could occupy your free time.

62851957.review:
I recommend this game, but only if you want a short, simple, not very challenging, "strategy" lite game that you can play through in 3-4 hours. I put quotes around "strategy" because there isn't much depth to it.I have finished the game twice in 12 hours with one restart because I messed up a simple choice in trying to get my last achievement for playing through on Hard. There are 3 save game spots, but only one per game. So, if you make a mistake with a choice, always around buying something, there is no going back. But since the play through is pretty quick, not much time is lost.

Warning: If you are playing through on Hard to get that achievement, you have to be very careful if you lose a battle. The game immediately asks if you want to lower the difficulty setting and it is easy to select the check mark (for yes) by mistake. That automatically lowers the difficulty to Normal and you can't get the Hard achievement in that play through.

There really isn't a story here, no real plot, and I have no idea about music since I usually play with my sound very low. The game map is very small with point and click to the next spot sort of thing. The enemy numbers, types, locations, etc., don't change. There are very few items to equip and about 7 units to choose from that become available at the same spots, limited only to your limited money at any given time. You essentially buy units, a few items to boost your 4 stats, and a few special attacks.

The game has no real replay value once you beat it and have all the achievements, if that is your thing. There is a Survival mini-game that unlocks, but it is just a beat 10 battle grids sort of thing without being defeated and you have at least one unit that isn't available in the regular game. However, in the Survival game, if you lose units, they are gone.

There is no grinding with the exception of if you lose a battle. Then you essentially restart in the spot just before the battle without really losing anything. You even make a little money. At the end of each battle, you get a monetary reward, minus the cost of replacing your units. So even if an entire unit is killed, you don't lose them or have to go back and buy them over again.

Your Hero doesn't appear on the battlefield, doesn't participate, and there isn't any character customization. The units are tiered in value and the most you can ever have is 15 total score in units. The units are valued from 1-5. Once you get the hang of combat, know the enemy strengths and weaknesses, and those of the units, the game isn't really that hard, even on Hard.

If you are new to "strategy" type games, I suggest playing through on Easy or Normal to get your feet wet. I played through on Normal the first time and got all but 4 achievements. It would be possible to play through once, on Hard, and get all the achievements, but most people would probably miss at least one, unless you read something about the achievements first.

This isn't a game that you are going to spend dozens of hours with, but it can be a refreshing break from those games that require a lot of strategy, planning, mental attention, and take days and weeks to finish.

I experienced no crashes and no identifiable bugs.

I wouldn't recommend paying full price for the series. But if you get it significantly discounted, the amount of play time and interest level is worth a few dollars. I have paid a lot more for movies that were shorter and a lot less entertaining.

Enjoy!

57682057.review:
Braveland is a casual play turn-based tactics game that provides a few hours of fun and relaxation.  Battles are small but resolved quickly and are not overly challenging or frustrating. There is some tactical thinking involved although the lack of units limits the range of tactics you can use.  You are only allowed a handful of units so it's difficult to set-up a good defensive formation and the most important tactical decision you have to make is what targets to prioritize.  Battles give experience win or lose which I was very glad to see and failure is not punished. Lose a fight? Your units come back fully healed, you get XP for any enemy units you managed to eliminate, and your troops take up a small collection for you giving you some gold after a defeat(although to be fair, not much, in fact a pittance compared to what you get for winning (as it should be.)) so that you can still progress and build yourself up after the loss, avoiding the danger of getting stalled and being trapped in a downward spiral where your only alternative is to start over from the beginning. Some battles are more challenging than others but there's usually some alternative battles you may have better luck at allowing you to build up your army before attempting the challenging battle again. I also liked that a "Retreat" button was provided so that if it becomes obvious you're not quite ready for that battle yet, you can end the misery and get out of it to come up with a new approach.
There are some RPG elements as you are cast as a commander of the army, an abstract character who is NOT represented on the battlefield, but who DOES level-up and grow stats and who can acquire gear that will improve those same stats, and those stats improve the abilities of your army.  Leveling up also improves a "Leadership" stat which increases the number of "soldiers" your units can contain which essentially equates to the "Hit Points" of your units, thus improving their survivability.
There are some drawbacks to the game, the low number of units was disappointing and, as I stated, limits tactical flexibility.  Also the lack of "Zones of Control" was frustrating as i would try to use my melee units to protect my ranged units only to have the enemy unit race past my melee unit to attack the ranged one. Yet another example of how the low number of units hurt the game. There is "terrain" on the battlefield that creates "choke points" but the low movement of friendly units vs faster movement of enemy units usually meant they would be through the choke point before you could completely block it.
There's also no "cover" mechanic, terrain blocks movement but has no effect on ranged fire so there's no tactical advantage to using the terrain except for attempting to block enemy movement, a task as I mentioned above, is difficult in itself due to lack of units and zones of control around them.
Yet despite these weaknesses I found the game enjoyable. With so many "rogue-like" games on the market with their OP units/bosses, it was nice to play a game you have a reasonable chance of beating, and still many of the battles were challenging without being frustrating.  There were still some battles lost, especially in the learning phase, but the reasonable handling of defeat kept it from being discouraging and maintained the "fun factor" keeping me engrossed in the game.  So don't buy this if you're looking for large, deep tactical battles with dozens of units and infinite options for deploying them, but if you want an entertaining diversion that will keep you engrossed for a few hours and is fun and challenging you could do worse than to pick up a copy of Braveland.

57329948.review:
Braveland is a turn-based game in a fantasy based setting. The story follows a man whose village was raided by bandits, and he seeks revenge. You start out with a few basic units and go on a journey with them. Each victory in battle gives you gold which can be used for various purchases. The map is pretty basic. It's got points that you click on to move to, and some paths branch to areas containing useful items that can improve your army. You can increase the amount of units you have by buying them at designated points. These points are hidden until you pass certain areas, and, generally, these are blocked off by an enemy group.
There's a gamemode outside of the story if the story isn't your type. You are given a starting amount of gold and purchase some units. After each match you are given some gold and can purchase units or other improvements seen in the story.

Bravelands was rather underwhelming. The story is poorly written: not only is it generic (with the main character being the typical "I want revenge" protagonist) everything seems repetitive or makes little sense. Every single enemy detour had the lines of "This business/group bad, we block people from going". There was no variation between, and I would have preferred it more if the game had simply forwent it. The main character isn't even playable; he just does... nothing? I wasn't too sure what he was there for since he wasn't in-game as a unit, nor did he seem to do anything except respond to enemy dialogue on the overworld map. This usually followed the lines of the enemy saying "I'm bad ohohoho" and then the protagonist responds "Evil must die" or some other stereotypical hero phrase.
The story seems as though it would simply end when the protagonist finds the bandits who raided his village. After all, he's a simple villager. Yet somehow he decides to take on an entire kingdom. Oh and for some reason the "villager" unit follows. Though that's not too bad, since removing an entire unit would be a poor decision, but there's no interaction or reasoning as to why the villagers, who had the reasoning for joining as "those bandits raided us", continue on the "hero's quest".
The gameplay was okay as well. The turn-based hexagonal-map was interesting at first, but there's hardly any strategy. It's a simple either you're stronger, or the enemy is. There's not much else to say about it. There weren't any notable gimmicks, except maybe a reviving enemy, which didn't revive half the time. There's a healer unit but that's one unit and has a limited amount of heals to use which hardly do much health in the first place.
Moving through the overworld map is tedious as well. The character has to walk to each section, and it follows the drawn path on said map. Which should be simple and somewhat expected, but the map is extremely long horizontally, and when there are some areas that still have units you can purchase, but those units are locked behind... story sections(?) it gets annoying to check every now and then. It takes over a minute to do so, and the characters don't even speed up to move there. It's a set traversing speed, and the least that could be done with this is either increasing the speed, allowing the player to skip this animation, or just pulling up the menu for purchasing from the set area.
The game is unclear on how to play as well. There's the starting tutorial, and the occasional pop-up saying "This is how you use item X" but that's it. The game doesn't explain what each stat does. For example, there's a Fury and a Initiative stat, which wasn't explicitly stated what they did. Survival mode doesn't explain that units have perma-death compared to the story mode.
The sound was average. The sound effects and grunting didn't sound like they were being recorded from a phone call made in a basement, but they were rather repetitive. They didn't have variation and got annoying quickly.
The animation for the game was fine too. Animations were simplistic, which is fine. Nothing too artsy about this game in the first place, nor would I expect such from a $5 game. 

Overall, Braveland is rather lackluster. Nothing sticks out, nothing seems interesting, and I ended up playing it just for the steam cards. If you want a passable story, look elsewhere; if you want something for short plays when you have no other game, perhaps this is the game for you.

56674659.review:
Braveland is a simple turned based strategy game that each turn is either used for attacking the enemy if they are close or moving around the battle field. Each turn the player must choose where they need to move their characters based on enemy locations and which are a more important target to take care of first. Now that is out of the way the big question is whether or not this game is a good game, simple is nice but doesnt always mean it is good. I will be reviewing the game in a pro/con style and end with my conclusion.

Pro:
      Each character is unique. Not only each character has different stats but some have pretty useful special abilities that when used properly can be a game changer. The game gets easier based on having more of the same characters since it adds an attack multiplier to the damage output but allows the characters to take more damage till all the backup of a specific character class is used up.

       The story is ok. It is about a town that gets ransacked by bandits and it is the job of a village to take up arms, build an army, and confront the leader of the bandits. Through the game you will run into some interesting dialogue by both bad guys and your teammates. Maybe some references to pop culture game stuff here and there.
Con:
      There is no grinding. So when you complete a location hub it is completed forever. That means you can not revisit it in hopes of killing more enemies to get more exp or money. It is a big deal when you think about it since money is used for getting more characters like more archers, thieves, ect or get gear. Money is a limited resource to get in the game and sucks that you will never have enough to get everything. It is not important to get everything but you can seriously make part of the game a bit more challenging than it should because you used your money to buy gear when you should have got more characters or unlock a skill for a character.

       Less amount of a character you have the weaker they are. For starter lets look at the healer. If you have just 2 which is the starting amount you do an awful amount of healing and damage output. It does not help that if cost 130 per healer making that entire class for the most part useless. Now if you look at any other class. When in combat and your amount of backup for a character drops to the last one. You might as well pull them away from combat since they will barely do any damage. It is annoying feature which it rewards having alot at the start but punishes the player when loosing more of that character by lowering the amount of damage output and maybe resistance. 

Conclusion:
      The game is functional, it is simple and could certainly use more polish but this is an early game for the dev team so expect this type of clunky quality for new games. It is not a bad game by no stretch of the imagination because it has a pretty good story and dialogue between characters. Though short it did lead to some funny moments. It does have problems with the combat with the stacking of characters improving stats but loosing the stack leads to poor stats within a fight. I would recommend the game because it was alright, probably pick it up on a sale and give it a try. It is not great but it is an ok game to play.

56649720.review:
Braveland is great casual turn based tactical strategy game that you play while taking breaks from larger games. games such as King's Bounty or Heroes of Might and Magic. I had earlier frustrations while playing King's Bounty and this game actually taught me my base strategies on how to play King's Bounty properly. I guess you can call Braveland a King's Bounty Lite game. It definately helps get your feet wet before diving into more complex games of the same genre.

I, however, do not recommend playing the sequels Wizard and Pirate. It will definately feel old and quickly loses it's charm compared to playing the first game.

TLDR;

Pros:
- Casual friendly
- Cute graphics
- Helps to learn basics of bigger games of the same genre (King's Bounty, HOMM)
- A great light game while taking breaks from bigger ones (Fallout 4, Skyrim, GTA, etc.)

Neutral:
- Minimal strategy needed.

Cons:
- Very short (5 hours for me)
- inferior sequels

Overall Rating: 4/5

55489327.review:
TLDR: Nice casual turn-based strategy game that's easy to understand and play. Great for when you want to relax with a fun strategy game and just de-stress for awhile.

Some may say complexity is better. To really have to work for any sort of accomplishment. Long slogs of complex maneuvering, unit sorting, micromanagement, and time to get anywhere. This is not that kinda game.

This game is...well...a game. Where you kick back for a few, enjoy a few battles, can walk away from and come back a time later and easily pick right back up from where you left off. Nothing complex and convoluted.

 And that suits me just fine for those times I just want a "quickie" to scratch the itch of playing these kind of turn-based, grid-based, strategy games. Just a simple good time, playing a good game with no brain drain that I can de-stress with or relax to before bed.

Something which this game does very well, and there ain't nothin' wrong with that. It's a solid, fun, relaxing game. Well made, enjoyable, with enough variety to play whack-a-mole half a dozen different ways. 

And isn't that what games are supposed to be? Fun, relaxing, time-wasters? If so, this fits the bill perfectly.

Braveland es un juego ''corto'' y MUY linear, literalmente jugué en fácil porque no tenia ganas de jugar en otra dificultad y para colmo me quedo trabada en una parte de la pelea en que te tenes que enfrentar contra 2 personajes distintos que son de nivel alto, demasiado alto, y se me hace imposible seguir al menos que reinicie el juego con otra dificultad lo cual no pienso hacer ni loca.

Es una lastima porque al principio le veía algo de entretenido, pero después te das cuenta que es muy repetitivo, todas las batallas son iguales y los personajes también, no hay muchas opciones en cuanto a tomar diferentes rutas en el juego, y lo estrategia por turnos es una mierda (ojo, solo en este juego, hay otros que implementan este sistema muy bien). 

Volvería a jugar a este juego en el futuro? NO, absolutamente no, no solo por la razones que describo arriba, con mirar otras reseñas te podes dar cuenta que es lo malo que tiene el juego en ciertas partes/zonas. 

Y la historia no es entretenida, es la típica historia de: ''Oh glorioso héroe desconocido que salio de la nada y heredo un arma valiosa de su padre, ¿puedes venir a salvarnos a todos de estos terribles ladrones que nos han robado y mataron a algunas personas de nuestro humilde pueblo?, pero no te vamos a ayudar para nada, ¿y después de salvarnos quieres que te demos cosas gratis?... JA! ve a conseguir dinero como los demás héroes de mierda, cuanto tengas lo suficiente para esta súper espada 3000 brillante con poderes mágicos, puedes volver, hasta entonces vete de aquí!

Me gustaría recomendarlo pero no puedo, solo le digo a aquellos que realmente lo quieran jugar, ¡COMPRARLO CON DESCUENTO!

5/10.

54252789.review:
Babby's First turn-based tactics game, accessible and simple, albeit rather short. While adapted from a mobile game, beyond some interface elements it's totally enjoyable on PC.

Anyways, it's kinda like Heroes of Might and Magic or King's Bounty or any of those other fantasy strategies, although lacking any overworld management, you'll only revisit locales to buy up new fighters once your unit limit increases or to get equipment you couldn't afford before. It's quite unrekarmable in that regard.

The core game combat meanwhile is alright, it's simple but there's quite some tactics and decisionmaking involved, at least on higher difficulties, and everything is pretty streamlined, although it can get rather dull where you have beaten most heavy duty enemies in melee and only defenseless spellcasters or rangers remain and you gotta beat them down, would be neat if sufficiently beaten the enemies would retreat.

There is some semblance of story here, but it's just generic half-witty banter and cliches. You're some peasant guy whose village gets robbed so he decides to avenge the robbers, going all the way up in villains chain of command killing them until the biggest baddest guy is defeated.

Overall, worst thing about this game is length, took me 3 hours to beat it. It's likely worth taking in a discounted bundle if you're a fan of this stuff, otherwise only consider it as an option only if you wanna introduce soembody to the genre, it's great choice for that.

My only gripes with the game were moving on the map got a little annoying as sometimes you need to backtrack several times to get something done...and not being able to speed that up was when you had to travel 20 'spaces' back was just simply...annoying. All in all, if you are looking for a relaxing strategy game and enjoy some silly childish humor then this is totally worth the purchase!

50983920.review:
Story mode:

Easy and Normal Difficulty are a charming and very forgiving strategy adventure suitable for children and adults. There is an excellent tutorial mode that leads the player through each element of game-play as it arises. The player's allies are always revived after every battle and even the defeated villains sometimes appear to survive.

Hard Difficulty, however, forces the player to make hard choices when deciding which allies to recruit. This is due to much smaller rewards for victory in battle and encourages some cynical gamesmanship. After a defeat the player is rewarded by not being compelled to pay to revive his fallen friends and receives a bonus for losing the battle! The longer the battle continues and thus the higher the casualties, the bigger the bonus. In Normal Difficulty, where resources are plentiful this is not an issue, but in Hard Difficulty where resources are scarce, it can be an expedient means to fully flesh out your army.

Survival Mode: 

In Survival Mode the player must successfully complete a series of ten battles in sequence. The player begins with a sum of gold to purchase an army from a random selection of up to three types of allies. Unlike Story Mode, lost allies are not automatically revived at the conclusion of battle.  Instead the player earns additional funds with each victory to purchase from three randomly selected allies, items and/or spells before each subsequent battle. What allies or items become available is not under the player's control. This can lead to losses being impossible to replace.

There is no tutorial in Survival Mode and there is no manual to refer to if the player forgets some aspect of game mechanics or potential abilities.

Minor Quibbles:

The target space and the currently active unit in battle are both surrounded by a hexagon of different shades of yellow. There is no undo feature if a unit is moved in error before an attack takes place.

Conclusion:

I would recommend this game for players interested in the short, charming, light fun of Normal Difficulty Story Mode.

I got this for free a long time ago when it was offered on humblebundle, I believe, though i’ve seen it free on steam from time to time as well. It's a turn based strategy game with a pretty linear pathway and very little story. I found it easy to 100% and I ran through two playthroughs of it, one of normal difficulty and one on hard. I would recommend it for as a time waster in between other games or while you're studying or listening to videos, but it doesn't have enough content to stand on its own. Could be a good entry for younger people wanting to try games of this genre, though I think children might struggle a bit with micromanaging units to obtain and send out. While it is pretty user friendly, you DRAG the map to move towards the next area, rather than clicking---which is common with mobile games so if your cursor is moving at the pace of a snail and you’re wondering why that is, it’s because you’re meant to drag to go to the next section of the map. The achievements generally are obtained from defeating section bosses, obtaining more powerful skills/spells, and being decked out in the best equipment in the game. All of which come pretty naturally with playing a game to completion. 


I'm not sure if I can say "BUY THIS" since it seems to go on sale for free quite a bit, but it’s definitely a fun little game that I didn't regret playing through a few times while listening to a podcast.

The graphics are decent, but gameplay wise, this game doesn't do anything terribly, but doesn't go anything really well either. The sum of it is just not very satisfying. Everything is feels a tiny bit off. 

I finished it and played a bit of survival but you never really get a chance to try out all the unit combinations because 1) it limits what you can bring to battle for no reason, and 2) you can't redo battles so once you run out of battles, that's it. It seems to be a recurring problem with a lot of strategy games where you earn end game units but have no opportunity to really use them. What you do get left with is rather shallow for a strategy game, and I guess for the asking price it's not too bad, but I really dislike having to leave out some units for others, especially since some of them are, in my opinion, not worth the squad points the game asks you go pay to field them in battle. I realize it's a difficult balancing decision to do in strategy games to not make things too easy, but it's a direction that I personally dislike. 

I also really dislike not being able to determine your units' positions at the start of each battle. It makes arranging a tank line for range units nearly impossible to do well. It's also very short as you can see by my play time. I also really took my sweet time to wander around and idled a bit.

The game features the old-school, hexagon grid system and with plenty of battles and a survival mode as a bonus. For the price its put I think its a fair deal, but anyone sane would get it on sale, like with other games on steam.

Starting with the Gameplay, the battle system and the stat system is really simple compared to other Turn-based Strategy games like Pit People from the Behemoth or the free-to-play Battle for Wesnoth. Featuring two squads fighting each other until one side eliminates all the troops on one side. Speaking of the troops they are handle by a number, showing how many troops are in that unit. For Example, a Archer unit might have 6 troops attached to it. if the number reaches zero, the unit dies. This health system can be somewhat annoying since the less troops you have the less damage the unit does which is a big problem for the tougher battles. On top of the reasonably short story mode, there is a endless survival mode if you want more of this simple battle system.

Now, visually the cartoonish style is very nice, It kinda reminds me of Dan Palaian from Behemoth's Art Style of cartoony characters. The music isn't anything too special, kinda generic medieval themes. Most of the game comes in the gameplay which is simple.

Overall, Braveland isn't the best Turn-Based Strategy, but for around 4.99 USD I'd say thats a OK price. Luckily they gave away free copies so the price isn't a big factor on my part. Another thing about this game is that it has two sequels Braveland Wizard and Braveland Pirate, which seem to be much bigger than the original.

49022326.review:
This is worth about $1

Standard overworld with fights which take place on a hex grid.  Your game pieces are various classes (archer, peasant, etc) that are in groups vs enemy groups.

It works without apparent bugs but so much basic mechanics information is missing and that is really irritating.

Missing is how damage is calculated so you don't really know if an attack will just wound or actually kill an enemy group.  Does having more in a group do more damage - they don't tell you?  Nowhere does it show how much your attack power is, or what the defensive rating of the foes are, so you're just playing a guessing game. How many are in each group of foes disappears when it's not your turn, etc. I'm really frustrated with the lack of information.

Then there is a lot of polish missing too.  In the tutorial where they teach how FURY works (the spell-casting) I killed the foes and ended the tutorial before I could even generate enough Fury from received enemy attacks. Its not rocket science how it works, but this is the kind of B grade polish you can expect. If you let the AI path-find on it's way to attack a foe, it doesn't show you where it plans to move... so it could end up on the wrong side and leave you without a blocking piece.  When you end a battle, to restock your army you have to walk all the way across the overworld to the barracks, etc... why is this way when restocking and buying equipment on the overworld is required after each battle? HP bars are nowhere to be seen, so when it's your Healers' turn, you have no idea which group will most benefit... these deficiencies are EVERYWHERE

I can't play a game like this.  But it is ok if you get it on sale. I feel like this would be better suited as a casual phone game.
49022326.developer_response:
Hi.

You could activate "eye-mode" in the upper-left corner. And you could see health bars, damage prediction and the number what creature will go first in this round. Hope it helps.

48503423.review:
A very good, albeit light squad RPG. You and your fellow peasants, archers and whatnot join you on a quest to bring down an evil king. While the game is short and can be completed in under 4 hours even on the hardest difficulty, it is very well paced. You continuously unlock new units, new spells and new abilities as well as new enemy types. 

Battling isn't the most complicated thing in the world either; units (you can have up to 5) move on a hex grid in a turn-based fashion. You have some spells, and every unit (save for one) has their own ability that has a small cooldown. It's all very easy to understand. If you want any challenge, play on the hardest difficulty; the game still won't be extremely difficult, but it will at least provide the occasional challenge. You earn gold which you can spend to increase the squad size of your units or on equipment.

If you are looking for a very light, bite-sized tactical RPG, I'd say this fits the bill. The only negative I have seen is that gold can be a bit sparse sometimes, so you have to spend it wisely; if you're out and still can't win a battle, the only way to get more gold is to repeatedly fail a fight (you will get some "failure gold") until you have enough to buy new stuff. Certainly not the best system, though I personally didn't have to use it. Otherwise, it's a very well-paced short tactical squad RPG with two surprisingly good music tracks.

Personal Rating: 9/10.

48482078.review:
RECOMMENDED WITH CAVEAT!  

If you're a seasoned player of turn-based or strategy games, you'll probably find the Braveland series of games to be short and a little dull.  I beat this game in about four hours of total playing, and I'm not exactly the greatest gamer of all time.  For someone like me, I think this game needs a LOT more for me to want to play it again anytime soon.  

Instead, I recommend this for kids and people who are new to these kind of games, or to games in general.  On that level, it may prove to be an enjoyable introduction to video games, and help someone get ready for something more serious, like Heroes of Might and Magic (which it resembles), Civilization, or some other kind of turn-based strategy game.  

So far, all the Braveland games are pretty basic.  However, "basic" is not a bad thing, and for what it is, I don't think this game is bad or deserves most of the thumbs-down ratings that it has gotten.  It works as it says it will, and it's not excessively complex.  That's more than I can say for many game series that are ridiculously hyped up and yet don't deliver; but that also might be too easy for me to say.

48371151.review:
Picked up free from a Humble Deal.

Yes, I'm a completionist.  Yes, I have all the achievements.  But can I say I have a good taste in my mouth at this point?  No, not really at all.

It starts out all right, and I didn't really mind the first hour or so.  My dislikes aren't anything that suddenly popped up, just things that annoyed me more and more as the game kept going on.

Let me list the good things first:
- the art is real cute
- animations are pretty solid
- interface is clean
- menu/map screen music is pretty good before it starts looping

The big problems are the combat and interface.

The combat mechanics are real basic: stats aside, all units function the same way (except the two ranged units, obviously).  You can unlock a special cooldown-based ability for each unit, some of which are slightly interesting and some of which are not.  Each turn comes down to using an ability if it's off cooldown, moving a few hexes, and attacking whichever enemy will counterattack you for less damage.  It's uninteresting, and every fight works out about the same way once you pick up the basic strategies.

[strike]Now maybe the gameplay would be tolerable if it was quick, but it's really, really not.  The interface is certainly easy to understand, but it's [i]slow[/i].  Animations can't be disabled or skipped, and you can't select another unit if one is moving or attacking.[/strike]  There are some hotkeys (which are not explained in game) that will save a few clicks, but they don't do enough to really make a difference.

EDIT: my bad Ragnar, I somehow missed the fast animation key in my 7 hours of play.  Thanks for pointing it out.

My overall verdict: looks good and is well polished, but slow, uninteresting gameplay makes this a skip in my books.
48371151.developer_response: Hi. You could activate "fast animation" mode in the upper-left corner of the battle screen.

48312650.review:
Easy, mindless fun for people who want to play a turn-based strategy without first earning a doctorate in the rules. I'm not sure how the equipment modifies my statistics, or what might be the optimal build for my party, because I really don't need to figure that out. Move a small band of figures around a hex grid and point at the enemies until they are dead, level up, then move a small band of figures around other hex grids and point at more powerful enemies until they are dead, and so on, until the final boss is dead. Then buy the next Braveland installment when its on sale.

This isn't an epic that you will play from noon until four in the morning. It's a snack that you can play as a break from studying or work. It's a perfect TBS for kids or for tired adults who have responsibilities.

44967498.review:
As a fan of Tactical RPGs, I saw that Braveland was on a sale and decided to pick it up and give it a shot. Although it seemingly does all that the developers intended, I was not impressed and quickly became bored of it. Some may enjoy it, particularly if they are into simpler strategy games, but the extremely casual nature of the game left me continually wishing there was more to it.

The story of the game is about as generic as they come; a simple country boy who's village was destroyed becomes a hero. The mechanics aren't much better than that. You and your army level up and improve with both experience and equipment but there's very little in the way of customizing your forces that most games in this genre have at this point. The combat itself is mediocre, feeling like a simplified version of the older entries in the Heroes of Might & Magic series.

Not a bad game, just one that failed to pique my interest, much less hold it. I would recommend it to those looking for a very casual Tactical RPG game that doesn't offer much but can pass a few minutes here and there. I would absolutely not recommend it to anyone looking for something deeper than that. Braveland does exactly what it says, nothing more, nothing less, and fails to bring any innovation to the genre.

44637699.review:
Received for free from a Humble Bundle promotion.

A pretty short, simple, and casual turn-based tactics RPG. I completed the campaign (on normal difficulty) within 3 hours.

Battles take place on a hexagon grid. You can only move, attack (melee or ranged based on the unit), defend, or wait. Most units have one 'special' attack that has a cooldown. Your units start on the left side of the screen (and the enemy on the right) and you just move towards them (or let them move to you) and attack. Later on you get access to the Fury meter which builds as you take damage. You spend the meter to cast spells (like deal damage or buff defense).

The campaign is a pretty simple story: chase after bandits who raided your village. The map is just traveling between circles (which represent an dialogue/store/battle). As you travel, you gain new units to use, find/buy upgrades and defeat harder and harder enemies until you reach the boss.

In normal difficulty, it had a pretty simple difficulty curve if you do every level to get every upgrade. I was able to beat almost all levels on the first try. There was one side path (of two battles) that was more difficult than the rest but it just meant revisiting the levels after progressing much further.

Your stats (that are determined by upgrades and equipment) are something like HoMM: you have generic buffs to units (Damage/Phys Resist/Mag Resist/Fury). I'm not really sure how much each buff helps or what is better to get because the game is pretty light on details of its mechanics.

Survival mode is a 10-round battle system where you start with 1500 gold and have selection of 3 types of units to hire. Any unit you lose is gone forever (so doing poorly will snowball). In between every round you get a random selection of 3 things (units/special attacks/Fury spells) to buy with the gold you've earned/saved up. While skill is a factor, it feels pretty dependent on luck because you may not get the chance to buy what you need to win. I tried a couple of times and on my best run I lost in round 8 with over 2000 gold in the bank because only the cheap units were available to buy (and I couldn't spend the rest of my gold).

Worth a look if you want a casual tactics RPG.

Other thoughts:
[*] Apparently, the story is 'book one' of a series.
[*] There are no keyboard shortcuts (as far as I know).
[*] There are often some obstacles that create chokepoints which may be good to stop all melee enemies from getting an attack in.
[*] Units only one counterattack per turn. You may want tankier or more disposable units to take the hit. On defense, chokepoints serve as a way to ensure 
[*] Physical (non-magical) ranged units are stuck with weaker melee attacks if they have to attack someone next to them (so you can take less damage if you corner their archers). Enemies will sometimes rush your back line so make sure your own archers have a buffer.
[*] Survival mode lets you use the Elementalist unit which is an enemy-only mage unit in the campaign.

44606657.review:
Braveland es un juego que recibí de forma gratuita de la página humble bundle.

Al principio no le tenía mucha fe al juego, ya que es del tipo de género que se basa en los combates por turnos y a mí no es que me atraigan mucho este tipo de juegos. Pero le di una oportunidad y la verdad me sorprendió bastante, ya que a pesar de ser un juego corto (ya que no dura más de 3 o 4 horas y si quieres los logros 6 a 7 horas) me entretuve bastante durante este tiempo.
Es un juego que a mi parecer es fácil inclusive en su mayor dificultad, pero hay ciertas batallas que tuve que ir a otros puntos del mapa que estaban más fáciles a conseguir dinero para poder seguir progresando ya que no podía hacer frente a ellas.
Sobre el mapa, al principio te da la impresión que es muy pequeño pero a medida que vas jugando se va expandiendo y con ello la cantidad de tropas disponibles, los "hechizos" si se les podría llamar así, las armaduras, las armas, los enemigos nuevos y varias zonas más que no se ven en el inicio.
Su historia no es que sea la mejor del mundo pero eso no es lo importante, lo que realmente importa es su jugabilidad, la verdad es algo básica pero es disfrutable y bastante fácil de entender.
Eso si hay ciertas cosas que el juego no te explica y debes darte cuenta tu solo/a quizás es algo negativo ya que al principio no me di cuenta que las tropas no se perdían y estaba súper preocupado ya que en mi mente decía si perdía una tropa buena, el juego se me haría cuesta arriba, pero bueno... son cosas pequeñas que no afectan en casi nada.
Algo que quizás me pueda quejar es que no hay muchas clases de tropas, de hecho solo hay tres a mi parecer, los guerreros, los arqueros y la sanadora. (Solo hay un tipo de sanador :l)
El estilo artístico me recuerda a castle crashers por lo "simple" y liso que es, es bastante agradable a la vista y da la sensación de estar jugando en un dibujo (bien hecho por cierto).

En resumen, el juego me gusto, eso sí con algunos peros. Sin embargo sigo insistiendo que es muy corto y no da tiempo a pensar estrategias. Es de esos juegos que te lo pasas en un fin de semana o algo parecido.
Te recomiendo que te lo compres si te gustan los juegos de combates por turnos y si te sobro dinero de alguna oferta de steam :).

44581281.review:
This is not good at all.

From a story perspective, there isn't really anything. There's nothing beyond "we're the good guys fighting against the bad guys" in any way.

The combat also has barely any strategy involved. You basically move units within range and attack. Special abilities have little relevance. There's no cover, terrain, positioning, anything, really. You have some abilities but, again, they're not very relevant to winning any battle. The game is extremely easy - if you have some problem, try another battle to gain gold to upgrade your units.

The map is basically a line with a few small branches (usually a battle and a shop of some kind). There is no reason to try one over another, though. You just visit them all (dumbly) and that's that.

Upgrades and equipment are really just a gold sink. You buy units (to upgrade) as you gain gold from battles, but, again, there are no choices. There aren't different builds for you to try. The planning exists to the extent that each unit type costs different amounts of gold, and so you can prioritize some over others. But, again, it makes very little difference.



The game works, but I can't imagine anyone getting a valuable experience out of this. It has an extremely basic skeleton all of the filler without any of special details that make a game worth playing. Oh well.

44563267.review:
Sometimes I want to give my brain a rest after a long day.  Then I'll jump into a casual game like Braveland and have some fun without too much frustration.  

If you have played any game with turn-based combat, then you can jump into Braveland easily.  In short, your village gets raided and you get to hero up and save the day.  Along the way you will pick up additional squad members like archers, knights, and healers.  As your squad gets more powerful, so do the enemies.  Fortunately, Braveheart does a good job of easing you into the game so even kids and first-timers can get the hang of the game.  If you're an achievement hunter, this should be easy to 100% as well.

My only negatives are that for some reason archers can shoot through me to the squad members behind me.  Also, items like rocks and tree will sometimes litter the playfield, but they don't seem to provide cover.  When you click the "?" aka help button, nothing pops up to explain what you are toggling, at least when using the mouse.  The game is controller compatible, so perhaps people will have better luck using it.

Still a fun game in spite of these minor issues.  I would probably pick up the remaining two games if there wasn't some weird sale where the entire trilogy costs less than the remaining two games.  Braveland was received free as part of a Humble Bundle promotion.

44561667.review:
-- Review for Linux version of this game --

Debian 9, Nvidia proprietary drivers.
Game worked OK, got 1 CTD on stats screen after survival mode game. Haven't played it after that so not sure if it's common behavior or if it affects survival mode ending screen (no, I don't want to test it more because that means I'll have to play this boring game for another 10-20 more minutes. no). Campaign worked good, no issues here.

About game itself. It's simple mobile game with cute graphics (tho it's not completely unique for units, you'll see alot of mirrored and recolored units) and very basic gameplay. Music is OK but lacks variety. Story is laughable or better to say no story just lame attempts to joke or whatever it was. No choices or if you have any choice it does not matter in game. Units have similar stats and their spells/powers are weak (I won't spoil but there's at least 2 types of units that is completely useless by their attack rate and powers, others suck but suck adequately). Repetitive time waster with cute graphics. Couple of strange achievements like "visit facebook ot twitter" and "complete game on hard". why I consider it strange? this game is so boring that I see no way how you would embrace this boredom for 2 times in a row just to get 1 achievement. Visiting social media sites to get an achievement is not valid request unless someone is giving away bunch of shovelware for that. But that's OK, FB link in game failed to work so I've got that achievement for nothing.

To summarize my experience I'd say this game is not something I'll keep in my library or would replay, it is 3 hours one sitting boring experience. It's boring not because it is simple, it is boring because it lacks balance, story, variety of units and armor/weapon, it lacks in every area possble. 
I wish we could have neutral review

Review:
This is not the first Braveland I've played, so I'm already familiar with the general functions and gameplay. I played the 2nd game 1st. So far the biggest difference I see is that you could use your "hero" in the beginning of the 2nd game, and so far, I haven't been able to use him in the 1st. Not sure if it will unlock at some point or not. Still is fun, and with a great tutorial. Very thorough; teaches you every time something new shows up. It's a relatively easy turn-based game, where the more units per squad you have, the more damage you do and less you take. For example if you have 10 archers in a squad, they will do far more damage than if you had 3. When the squad takes damage, it doesn't just immediately die. The amount of units in the squad decreases, so 10, 9, 8 etc in this example. Healers can increase the squad count back up. What's also nice about this game series, is they show you how hard the enemies around you are, so you know which order would be best suited to go in, and whether you should enhance your squads or not. Only took 4 hours to beat this one. A lot more game time for their Pirates version. They all seem copy paste games with just different plots, but still kind of the same.

41510490.review: “Braveland” is the first part in a trilogy of turn-based tactical adventure games that have a distinctive HOMAM-style (minus the city-building part and, let’s be honest, strategy). The story is the classic fairy-tale of “farmer whose village has been plundered by bandits” who gathers some rednecks and goes on a journey to beat the evil man who caused all this. On that journey, you’ll get seven types of units to combine in your army, who learn special abilities (if you pay for them) during the story, and your hero will also pick some spells and can buy stuff to enhance his abilities. Combat takes place on the typical hex-board where you can maneuver your picked units to defeat opponents with various degrees of difficulty, but even the most difficult ones can be easily defeated with some tactical savvy. The most distinguishing feature of this game is the graphics – all sceneries and characters are nicely drawn and animated in a cartoonish style that is cute and precise at the same time. This game is ideal for kids who want to learn the basics of tactical combat with units, but can be attractive for grown-ups too for its light humor and playability.

And yep - it's marked as casual. So just judge our game as light strategy for rest between really big and hard games. Anyway thanks for the review. Have fun!

41030332.review:
A good little turn based strategy fantasy game that goes on for a few hours. Fairly challenging. It is similar in the battles to Heroes of Might and Magic and King's Bounty. It has a good little positive story, decent graphics and good sound for what it is. It does not go very in depth with spells and character customization but it does not need to, it's very good as it is and for what it is- a lighter experience in this genre. It is very user friendly. You will understand everything you need to do very quickly. What I especially like about it is that you only recruit troops once and if you lose them after the battle they are automatically replenished on the spot for some gold-no tedious backtracking like in the mentioned bigger games. The developers really created a user friendly, pleasant and enjoyable experience.Also, as an RPG fan, the progressio, levelling, item acquiring and army growth are very enjoyable-you feel the power, although bigger challenges you will also arrive very soon.
I recommend it to anyone who likes TBS games and especially for people who liked Heroes and King's Bounty- Braveland is lovable. And when you are done with it, it has sequels which I definitely will also play. Also for anyone like me who loves to grow in RPG games.

Warning: Unlike Heroes and King's Bounty, you do not have castle or much freedom so do not expect this. Braveland follows a linear path and story and for what it is, it is very enjoyable. Expect this and you will like it.

33889573.review:
I recommend this game.  Yes, it is a watered-down version of 'Heroes of Might and Magic,". . . but I really like Heroes of Might and Magic.  Certainly the mechanics are familiar to anyone who has played HoMM or Kings Bounty: you fight turn-based battles while continuously leveling up your General and moving your troops around.  It is faithful to HoMM-1 in that you have 4 stats on your General and those 4 stats also beef up your troops.  It is more like the original Kings Bounty (the one from around 1990, not the current series) in that you just move around one single General, stopping at taverns to replenish your troops.  You don't have to worry about conquering gold mines or garrisoning castles.  Think of this as a single scenario map, and decide for yourself it you want to try it.  It has a free Demo if you're not sure.  Personally I had a blast playing it, and I got many hours of playtime out of it.  And I still haven't tried it at the Hard difficulty.  

One note for those of you who hate bugs and crashes: this game ran perfectly on my very old system.  No crashes, no bugs, no problems at all.  

The only negative is the lack of replayability; once you've played through on each difficutly level, that's pretty much it.
